row.cell:
“Dry bed of stream” indicated on map
was at the bottom of a wide, deep gully,
between hospital and parade grounds.
Do not recall these buildings.

91 Southern half offices. Northern half
pharmacy, storeroom and quarters of
one or two Hosp. Corps N. C. Os.

92 S. end a room for sick officers.
Remainder of S. half was the fever ward.
N. end was barred as “lock ward” for
sick prisoners. Remainder of N. half
was venerial ward. (NOT 104.)

96 NO - not mess but patients' kitchen.
Should be turned half around and moved
closer to 97. It was possible to step
from the door of one into the door of
the other.

97 NO - This is location of patients' mess.
It was much closer to veranda around
wards. There was only a small plat-
form between bottom of verands steps
and door of mess.

104 NO. See my comments 92. Believe this
and not 110 was quarters female nurses.
Am not certain of any of these except 108.

110 Don't think so. See 104. Believe
this was the canvas roofed, but other-
wise open, shelter for the horse sup-
posedly for the Post Surgeon but act-
ually used by the orderly. There was
such a shelter at about this location.
I recall this distinctly as I had the
orderly detail for a while.

Do not recall details of yellow fever
hospital clearly enough to make my
comments of value.

143 Boiler house. A very small structure
to house wood-burning boiler for hot
water supply. It was in the space
between wards 91 and 92. This was
NOT connected, by a walk, with the
elevated walk from wards 91 and 92.

? Toilets and bath. (Not shown.)
This building was between wards 91 and
92, north of the elevated walk connect-
ing the verandas of those wards.
Its single entrance was, from the walk,
midway between 91 and 92.
